etymologies: Middle English (in the sense ‘something given to support an undertaking that someone will fulfill an obligation’): from Old French surte, from Latin securitas (see security)

definitions: a person who takes responsibility for another's performance of an undertaking, for example their appearing in court or the payment of a debt.
shortDefinitions: person who takes responsibility for another's performance of undertaking

definitions: money given to support an undertaking that someone will perform a duty, pay their debts, etc.; a guarantee

examples.text: the judge granted bail with a surety of $500

shortDefinitions: money given to support undertaking that someone will perform duty, pay their debts

definitions: the state of being sure or certain of something

examples.text: I was enmeshed in the surety of my impending fatherhood

shortDefinitions: state of being sure or certain of something
